experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: The vanishing of complex-structure moduli (h²¹→0) has no causal effect on the structure of flux-stabilization equations or the Kähler metric. Equivalently, period integrals, their derivatives, and the mirror map remain smooth and well-behaved as h²¹→0, and the stabilization locus does not exhibit attractor behavior or metric criticality.
experiment.statistical_test: Two-part test: (1) Fit power-law scaling ∂Π_a/∂h²¹ ~ c₁(h²¹)^{-α₁} and κ(Hess W) ~ c₂(h²¹)^{-α₂} over 10–15 logarithmically spaced sample points h²¹∈[0.01, 1]. Use least-squares regression on log–log data, compute R² > 0.90 and 95% CIs for exponents. Reject H₀ if α₁ > 0.5 and α₂ > 1 with p < 0.05 (two-sided t-test on fitted exponents vs. null: exponents = 0). (2) Count rank-deficiency signature: number of near-zero singular values of ∂²W/∂z_i∂z_j should increase as h²¹ decreases; formalize via threshold σ_min < 10^{-3} (smallest singular value). Reject H₀ if the rank drops by ≥1 at h²¹ = 0.01 vs. h²¹ = 1 (Fisher exact test on rank-change indicator).
experiment.minimum_detectable_effect: α₁ ≥ 0.5 and α₂ > 1 (power-law exponents); Spearman ρ(log h²¹, log κ) < −0.80 (strong monotonic scaling); Δ(rank) ≥ 1 and Δ(dim Stab) ≥ 1 (structural change); R² > 0.88 on log–log fit. Total sample size: n = 15 h²¹ values. Power = 90% to detect α > 0.5 with measurement noise σ_noise ~ 5% of signal (typical in numerical PDE).
experiment.statistical_power_notes: Numerical experiments with deterministic (not stochastic) output. Convergence criterion: achieve relative error < 10^{-6} in period integrals (via MPFR or adaptive quad rules). For each h²¹, solve PF system to convergence; repeat 3 times with different mesh sizes to confirm stability. No hypothesis test needed per se, but exponent fit (n=15 points, log–log) achieves >90% power to reject H₀: exponent=0 if true exponent α > 0.5 (assuming 5% relative noise). Stabilization-locus rank drop is categorical; test with binomial: probability of observing rank drop at ≥10 out of 15 h²¹ samples under H₀ (rank constant) is <0.01 by Clopper–Pearson.
limitations: Choice of one-parameter family: results may be family-dependent. Mitigation: test on 2–3 different families (e.g., K3-fibered, hypersurface dP constructions, orbifold limits) and cross-validate scaling exponents.

Numerical convergence near h²¹→0: Picard-Fuchs system may become ill-conditioned; requires arbitrary-precision arithmetic (MPFR) and careful series resummation. Mitigation: use modular-form expansions and analytic continuation; precompute normal forms.

Mirror-map singularities: may be non-algebraic (e.g., logarithmic, transcendental); Kähler metric pull-back may diverge before rigidity is reached. Mitigation: regularize via ε-expansion or alternative coordinates; document domain of validity.

Flux choice: superpotential W depends on flux background G_3. Different fluxes may show different stabilization behavior. Mitigation: test on a representative set of fluxes (e.g., generic Hodge-diamond-preserving fluxes).
Computational cost: high-precision arithmetic and hypergeometric-series resummation are expensive. Parallelization and caching of PF solutions recommended.
Absence of wet-lab validation: all results are mathematical/numerical; physical interpretation requires string-theory interpretation and consistency checks with swampland conjectures.
experiment.requires_followup: This is a computational study; wet-lab analogue does not apply. However, the results should be cross-validated via: (1) Comparison with existing moduli-stabilization codes (e.g., STRINGVACUA, MCCT) on benchmark CY3s (X_{3,2,1}, others) to verify period-integral accuracy. (2) Analytic verification: derive PF normal forms for the test family by hand or via symbolic algebra, confirm exponents α, β theoretically if possible. (3) Physics interpretation: if the hypothesis is confirmed, a follow-up study should (a) test whether the rigid limit is an attractor in the K-moduli landscape via flow equations, (b) investigate whether de Sitter uplift mechanisms (anti-D3, D-term, F-term) remain viable near rigidity, and (c) check consistency with swampland conjectures (de Sitter, tadpole, weak gravity) at the proposed attractor locus.

hypotheses.source_question: Does the choice of O3/O7-plane orientifold projection (concept B) causally determine which complex-structure stabilization loci are compatible with large-volume Kähler moduli (concept A), and if so, can this constraint be computed from the period vector alone?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that the choice of O3/O7-plane orientifold projection causally determines the set of accessible complex-structure stabilization loci via tadpole-enforced flux quantization constraints, such that for a given CY3 (here GL=12), the period vector alone permits computation of which flux configurations are orientifold-compatible, and this causal chain predicts the large-volume Kähler scaling exponent with at least 80% fidelity across all O3/O7 choices.
hypotheses.mechanism: Orientifold-choice (O3/O7 wrapping configuration) → tadpole charge constraint N_flux(O3/O7) → restricted flux lattice Λ_flux(N_flux) → allowed superpotential landscape {W(z, F) : F ∈ Λ_flux} → discrete set of stabilization loci z_stab → Kähler back-reaction via mirror map (t^a = ∂F_0/∂X^a where F_0 encodes period derivatives) → predictable volume scaling V_eff(τ_s). The causal direction is: orientifold choice → tadpole → flux lattice → stabilization, NOT the reverse.
hypotheses.prediction: For the GL=12 D₆-symmetric CY3, at least 70% of the 5 D₆-invariant complex-structure stabilization loci predicted by solving ∂W/∂z_i = 0 over all flux quantizations allowed by a given O3/O7 choice will satisfy the Swampland de Sitter constraint |∇V|/V ≥ c_dS (estimated c_dS ≥ 0.5 in string units), and the predictive power (matching stabilization loci to O3/O7 choice via period data alone) will exceed 0.8 (measured as precision = true_positives / (true_positives + false_positives)).
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If, after enumerating all O3/O7 orientifold choices for GL=12 and computing tadpole-allowed flux lattices, the stabilization loci identified by solving ∂W/∂z_i = 0 do NOT correlate with O3/O7 choice (i.e., precision < 0.5 — more than half of predicted loci are achievable under multiple incompatible O3/O7 configurations), or if the volume scaling exponent V_eff(τ_s) varies by more than 50% across the same O3/O7 choice under different tadpole-compatible flux choices, the hypothesis is refuted. Equivalently: if Swampland compliance is independent of orientifold choice (χ² test of association p > 0.05), the causal chain is broken.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: Precision ≥ 0.80 (at least 80% of stabilization loci are uniquely recoverable from O3/O7 + period data); Cramér's V ≥ 0.40 for association between O3/O7 choice and stabilization locus membership; volume scaling exponent agreement ≤ 10% relative error across independent flux configurations within the same O3/O7 choice.

experiment.approach: Enumerate all O3/O7-plane orientifold configurations for the GL=12 CY3 polytope (h¹¹=17, h²¹=20, D₆ symmetry), compute tadpole charge N_flux for each, solve the GKZ Picard-Fuchs system for the 5 D₆-invariant complex-structure moduli to obtain period vectors Π_a(z) numerically near all singular loci (conifold, large complex structure), construct the superpotential W(z, F) = G_a(F)Π_a(z) for all flux configurations in the tadpole-allowed lattice, find stabilization loci by solving ∂W/∂z_i = 0, and map each locus back to Kähler moduli via mirror map (t^a = ∂F_0/∂X^a) to extract volume scaling. Correlate orientifold choice with stabilization locus membership and Swampland compliance (|∇V|/V).
steps: Construct the toric fan for GL=12 and extract the GLSM charge matrix and polytope Δ⁻.
Enumerate all possible O3/O7-plane orientifold involutions compatible with the D₆ symmetry (expected: 2–4 geometrically distinct choices).
For each orientifold, compute the tadpole charge N_flux = integral over O3/O7 tadpole density and flux quantization lattice rank via intersection form on H_3(CY3).

Solve the GKZ Picard-Fuchs differential system {L_i Π = 0 : i=1,…,5} using numerical integration (e.g., ODE solver in Mathematica or Python via giac backend) at sample points z = (z_1,…,z_5) in the moduli space, focusing on conifold (z_j → 1 for j=1,2) and large-complex-structure (|z_j|→∞) regions. Store Π_a(z) as lookup table.
For each tadpole-allowed flux configuration F ∈ Λ_flux (G_a ∈ ℤ, sum G_a N_a ≤ N_flux), interpolate/evaluate W(z,F) = G_a Π_a(z) on the moduli space.
Solve ∂W/∂z_i(z,F) = 0 numerically for each (F, orientifold) pair using Newton-Raphson; record stabilization locus z_stab(F, O3/O7) and check non-degeneracy (Hessian rank = 5).
For each stabilization locus, compute the Kähler potential K = -ln(-i ∫ Ω∧Ω̄) - 2ln(V) using periods and their derivatives; extract volume scaling exponent a via fitting V_eff ∝ e^{a τ_s}.
Compute |∇V|/V at each stabilization locus (gradient w.r.t. all moduli) and test Swampland conjecture |∇V|/V ≥ 0.5.
Build contingency table: rows = O3/O7 choices (e.g., 'O3–O7a', 'O3–O7b'), columns = stabilization locus membership. Compute Cramér's V and χ² test.
Compute precision = (# stabilization loci uniquely identifiable from (z_stab, O3/O7) pair) / (total # distinct z_stab). Report 95% CI via bootstrap (1000 resamples of flux configurations).
tools: Macaulay2 or Singular — toric geometry, GKZ computation from polytope
Mathematica (NSolve, NDSolve, InterpolatingFunction) or SageMath — GKZ ODE solving, period interpolation
CYtools / Sage — CY intersection form, mirror map, Picard-Fuchs system from toric data (if available; fallback: manual GKZ construction)
Python (scipy.integrate.odeint, scipy.optimize.newton, numpy) — numerical period computation, stabilization locus solver
R or Python (scipy.stats.chi2_contingency, statsmodels) — contingency analysis, Cramér's V, precision estimation
Public CY database (Kreuzer-Skarke) — polytope data for GL=12
experiment.estimated_effort: 3–4 weeks compute: (1 week) polytope + GKZ + orientifold enumeration, (1 week) period ODE solving + verification, (1 week) superpotential + stabilization locus computation, (1 week) Kähler + Swampland analysis + contingency table + statistical tests.
experiment.data_requirements: KS polytope ID for GL=12 (public); GLSM charge matrix (derivable from polytope); O3/O7 tadpole formulas (literature); numerical ODE tolerances (1e-10 relative, 1e-12 absolute for period stability).
experiment.expected_positive: For ≥70% of the O3/O7 choices tested, stabilization loci computed from (z_stab, F) pairs cluster by orientifold choice with Cramér's V ≥ 0.40 (p < 0.05); precision of O3/O7 → z_stab prediction ≥ 0.80; volume exponent a agrees within 10% for different F within the same O3/O7; ≥60% of loci satisfy |∇V|/V ≥ 0.5 (Swampland consistent) and this fraction correlates with O3/O7 tadpole constraint (higher N_flux → higher dS compatibility).
experiment.expected_negative: Cramér's V < 0.30 (weak/no association) or p > 0.05 (no statistical correlation) between O3/O7 and z_stab; precision < 0.50 (random guessing of O3/O7 from locus); volume exponent scatter >50% within same O3/O7; <40% Swampland compliance showing no correlation with tadpole choice (consistent with untethered flux landscape).
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: Complex-structure stabilization loci are independent of O3/O7 orientifold choice, conditional on tadpole quantization. Equivalently: Cramér's V(O3/O7, z_stab) = 0 and precision(O3/O7 → z_stab) = 1/k where k = number of O3/O7 choices (random classification).
experiment.statistical_test: Pearson χ² test of association between O3/O7 choice (categorical, 2–4 levels) and stabilization locus cluster membership (categorical, ≤20 levels for 5 moduli discretized). H₀ rejection criterion: p < 0.05, Cramér's V ≥ 0.40. Supplementary: logistic regression predicting O3/O7 from (z_stab, V_eff, |∇V|/V), report area-under-ROC ≥ 0.85 as evidence of strong causal encoding.
experiment.minimum_detectable_effect: Cramér's V ≥ 0.40 (medium effect, ~N=60 flux configurations across ~3 O3/O7 choices); precision ≥ 0.80 (equivalent to 80% of z_stab correctly classified to O3/O7); logistic regression AUC ≥ 0.85. With estimated ~2–4 O3/O7 choices and ~50–100 stabilization loci (across flux quantizations), these are achievable with α=0.05, power=0.90.
experiment.statistical_power_notes: Design is deterministic (no randomness in ODE solving, only discretization error); convergence criterion is GKZ solution accuracy (relative error in Π_a < 1e-8 verified via Wronskian identity det[Π_a, L_i Π_a] = 0). Contingency χ² assumes ≥5 expected counts per cell; if violated, use Fisher exact or Monte Carlo permutation (10,000 permutations). Precision 95% CI via 1000 bootstrap resamples of flux configurations. For logistic regression, assume effect size (O3/O7 encoding in moduli) is medium-to-large (Nagelkerke R² ≥ 0.5); with ~60–80 independent flux samples, power >0.90 for AUC > 0.85.
limitations: GL=12 is a single instance; generalization to other polytopes requires repetition (e.g., GL=14, Dwork family). Results may be GL-specific due to its D₆ symmetry and moderate Hodge numbers.

Period ODE solver uses numerical integration; truncation error and branch-cut ambiguity near singularities could introduce spurious correlations. Mitigation: validate against known limits (conifold monodromy, large-volume asymptotics) and cross-check with independent methods (e.g., series expansion, if available).

O3/O7 enumeration assumes all involutions compatible with D₆ are geometric; non-geometric orientifolds or moduli-dependent choices could expand the search space. Will be addressed by explicit involution classification.

Flux quantization lattice assumes standard Type IIB integrality; brane wrapping modes and fractional fluxes (if relevant) are not included. Impact expected to be small for GL=12 given low Hodge numbers.
Swampland de Sitter conjecture threshold (c_dS ≥ 0.5) is not universally agreed; sensitivity analysis over c_dS ∈ [0.3, 1.0] should be performed.

Kähler moduli back-reaction via mirror map is 1-loop in type IIB; perturbative corrections (α') and non-perturbative (D3-instanton) are not included. Limits applicability to weak-coupling regimes. Mitigation: restrict analysis to regions where K-moduli are not deeply stabilized (W_0 << 1 not necessarily enforced).
experiment.requires_followup: Mathematical/topological follow-up (not wet-lab): once computational results identify O3/O7-dependent stabilization loci, (1) derive exact mirror-map formulas for GL=12 to translate z_stab to Kähler coordinates analytically, (2) compute Yukawa couplings κ_abc at predicted stabilization loci and test against known D₆-invariant Yukawa texture, (3) verify tadpole-conjecture compliance (N_flux ≤ (2/3) h²¹ = 13.3 for GL=12; test whether observed N_flux values respect this bound). If results suggest strong causal determination, perform analogous computation on a second polytope (e.g., GL=14) to validate transferability. No wet-lab step required for primary hypothesis test, but results would motivate downstream string-model building (explicit brane/flux construction) and cosmological modeling.

hypotheses.source_question: Does the mirror symmetry map between type IIA and type IIB compactifications establish a causal constraint whereby IIA period geometry (via Picard-Fuchs systems on the mirror) determines the IIB Kähler moduli stabilization landscape through the prepotential F and mirror map t^a = ∂F/∂X^a?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that the type IIA prepotential F(X^a) reconstructed from Picard-Fuchs period integrals on the mirror CY3 causally determines the type IIB Kähler moduli metric K_ab and thus constrains the stabilization landscape by requiring that the third derivatives of F match the triple intersection numbers F_abc of the IIB Calabi-Yau to within threshold precision, and that violating this constraint makes KKLT/LVS hierarchies unachievable.
hypotheses.mechanism: Mirror symmetry establishes a deterministic map: type IIA A-periods computed via GKZ Picard-Fuchs operators on the mirror lattice yield the prepotential F(X^a), which constrains the type IIB Kähler potential via the mirror map coordinates t^a = partial F/partial X^a. The Kähler metric K_ab = partial^2 K / partial t^a partial t^b is then rigid. This rigidity propagates into the scalar potential V(z,t) = e^K[K^ij D_i W D_j W-bar + 3|W|^2], making stabilization minima IIA-determined. Misalignment between IIA-derived K and IIB flux superpotential W causes the gradient ∇V to violate swampland bounds or destabilize geometric moduli.
hypotheses.prediction: For the GL12/D6 family (h11=17, h21=20, reduced to 5 D6-invariant complex-structure moduli via symmetry), solving the Picard-Fuchs system to extract F(X) to precision |partial^3 F/partial X^a partial X^b partial X^c - F_abc^IIB| less than 10^-8 relative error on intersection numbers will yield a Kähler metric K_ab such that the KKLT hierarchy |W_0| less than or equal to 0.1 is achievable at a stabilization locus with volume V greater than 10^4 at small string coupling g_s less than 0.2. If |partial^3 F/partial X^a partial X^b partial X^c - F_abc^IIB| greater than 10^-6, the compatible stabilization region shrinks by more than 50 percent or becomes empty.
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: The hypothesis is refuted if solving the Picard-Fuchs system to high precision and extracting F(X) yields a third-derivative mismatch |partial^3 F/partial X^a partial X^b partial X^c - F_abc^IIB| greater than 10^-6 relative error, AND simultaneously KKLT-type minima with W_0 less than 0.1 and V greater than 10^4 can still be achieved when imposing flux-mediated complex-structure stabilization. Alternatively refuted if the mirror map t^a = partial F/partial X^a is multivalued or discontinuous at the stabilization locus, violating the assumption of a rigid geometric map.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: Explained variance R-squared greater than 0.85 (IIA-derived K_ab explains at least 85 percent of variance in IIB intersection-number constraints). Equivalently, relative error on prepotential third derivatives less than 1 times 10^-6. Volume reduction in KKLT feasible region: if mismatch exceeds 10^-6, the compatible volume range contracts below 10^3, representing one order of magnitude contraction.

experiment.approach: Numerically solve the Picard-Fuchs differential system for type IIA periods on the mirror of the GL12/D6 Calabi-Yau family near conifold and large complex-structure limits. Extract the prepotential F(X^a) to high precision, compute mirror-map coordinates t^a and Kähler metric K_ab. Cross-validate by computing type IIB periods directly and verifying that partial^3 F/partial t^a partial t^b partial t^c matches triple intersection numbers F_abc. Use IIA-derived K and F to scan for flux-stabilized minima in the type IIB scalar potential and quantify volume and hierarchy constraints imposed by IIA geometry.
steps: Obtain the GLSM charge matrix (toric Fano polytope) for the mirror of GL12/D6. Extract the lattice of exponents and construct the GKZ differential operators L_i that annihilate type IIA periods.

Numerically solve L_i Π_a(X) = 0 using Runge-Kutta or spectral methods near a conifold point and large complex-structure point. Compute at least 4 independent period solutions Π_a to relative precision less than 10^-12 using adaptive mesh refinement and error control.
From the periods, extract the prepotential F(X^a) using the relation partial F/partial X^a = Π_a. Fit F as a polynomial plus transcendental logarithmic terms in the moduli.
Compute the mirror-map coordinates t^a = partial F/partial X^a at the marked point. Verify that t^a are single-valued and span the expected dimension of 5 for GL12/D6 with D6 symmetry.

Compute the Kähler metric K_ab(t) = partial^2 K/partial t^a partial t^b by taking second derivatives of the prepotential. Extract Kähler class coordinates and verify against known intersection-form structure.
Independently solve the type IIB Picard-Fuchs system for the same mirror family. Compute Yukawa couplings F_abc^IIB as intersection numbers on the B-model Calabi-Yau directly.
Compare: compute |partial^3 F/partial t^a partial t^b partial t^c - F_abc^IIB|/|F_abc^IIB| for all nonzero components. Flag any triple with relative error greater than 10^-6.

Using IIA-derived K_ab and a standard flux superpotential W = G_0 + sum G_a Π^a (or KKLT-type non-perturbative deformation), numerically minimize the IIB scalar potential V(z,t) = e^K[K^ij D_i W D_j W-bar + 3|W|^2] over complex-structure moduli z subject to minimization over Kähler moduli t. Record minima with |W_0| less than 0.1 and measure the range of achievable volumes V.

Repeat stabilization scan using a mismatched Kähler metric K-prime obtained by adding random perturbations of amplitude delta K approximately 10^-6 times K to simulate imprecision. Compare achievable (V, W_0) regions for K (IIA-determined) versus K-prime.

Test swampland de Sitter conjecture: compute |∇V|/V at each minimum and check if it violates |∇V| greater than or equal to c times sqrt(3/2) for c approximately 0.4. Correlate violations with mismatches in F_abc.
tools: Gröbner basis polynomial algebra system (Macaulay2, Singular) for GKZ operator construction
Numerical ODE solver (scipy.integrate.odeint, Mathematica NDSolve) for Picard-Fuchs integration
High-precision arithmetic library (mpmath, Arb, Pari/GP) for 12-digit period computation
SymPy or Mathematica for symbolic differentiation of prepotential and Kähler metric
Numerical optimization (scipy.optimize, L-BFGS-B) for stabilization locus search
KS Kreuzer-Skarke database or toric Fano polytope library for mirror pair data
Intersection-number tables from literature or direct toric geometry computation for F_abc^IIB validation
Custom Python or Mathematica orchestration script for pipeline and comparison tables
experiment.estimated_effort: 6 to 10 weeks of concentrated compute. Initial period integration 1 to 2 weeks. Prepotential fitting 1 week. Kähler-metric construction 1 week. Type IIB periods and Yukawa validation 1 to 2 weeks. Stabilization scans 2 to 3 weeks. Total CPU time approximately 500 to 2000 core-hours, parallelizable over flux sectors and moduli-space regions.
experiment.data_requirements: KS polytope and lattice data (public, less than 1 GB). GKZ operator coefficients (derived, approximately 1 MB per family). Pre-computed Yukawa couplings from literature or computed de novo (approximately 100 MB). No proprietary data required. Storage approximately 10 GB for intermediate period values and potential evaluations.
experiment.expected_positive: Picard-Fuchs periods extracted to precision less than 10^-12 relative error. Third-derivative mismatch |partial^3 F/partial t^a partial t^b partial t^c - F_abc^IIB|/|F_abc^IIB| less than 10^-6 for at least 90 percent of independent Yukawa components. Kähler metric K_ab(t) reconstructed uniquely. IIA-determined K yields KKLT-type minima with |W_0| less than or equal to 0.1 and V greater than 10^4 achievable. Mismatched K-prime fails to support the same volume range, shrinking compatible region by greater than 50 percent. Swampland gradient |∇V|/V correlates with F_abc precision with R-squared greater than 0.7.
experiment.expected_negative: Picard-Fuchs system is numerically ill-conditioned and cannot be solved to greater than 10^-6 precision. Alternatively, third-derivative mismatch |partial^3 F/partial t^a partial t^b partial t^c - F_abc^IIB|/|F_abc^IIB| greater than 10^-6 for more than 20 percent of Yukawa components, indicating the prepotential is not rigidly determined by IIA geometry. Or IIA-derived K allows KKLT minima with arbitrary (V, W_0) independent of F_abc precision, proving IIA geometry does not causally constrain IIB stabilization.
experiment.null_hypothesis: H0: The type IIA prepotential F(X^a) extracted from Picard-Fuchs periods does not causally constrain the type IIB Kähler moduli metric K_ab(t). The third derivatives of F are statistically independent of type IIB intersection numbers F_abc^IIB, and the type IIB stabilization landscape (achievable W_0, V ranges) is invariant under variations in K_ab amplitude consistent with IIA-precision uncertainty.
experiment.statistical_test: Pearson correlation coefficient rho between partial^3 F/partial t^a partial t^b partial t^c and F_abc^IIB, tested against H0: rho equals 0. One-sided test reject H0 if rho greater than 0.85 with p less than 0.05 (approximately 25 to 30 independent Yukawa components, Bonferroni-corrected alpha approximately 0.002). Secondary F-test for variance in compatible (V, W_0) regions under K (IIA) versus K-prime (perturbed), testing H0: var(V|K) equals var(V|K-prime). Reject if F-statistic greater than 1.5 (95 percent confidence, approximately 50 stabilization minima per configuration).
experiment.minimum_detectable_effect: Correlation rho greater than 0.85 between partial^3 F/partial t^a partial t^b partial t^c and F_abc^IIB with approximately 25 to 30 components. Relative error on prepotential third derivatives less than 1 times 10^-6. Volume-shrinkage effect: greater than 50 percent reduction in compatible (V, W_0) region when K is perturbed by delta K approximately 10^-6 times K (detectable with 40 to 60 stabilization minima per configuration, power greater than 0.85).
experiment.statistical_power_notes: Yukawa-validation test: approximately 25 to 30 independent third derivatives per D6-symmetric family. Assuming effect size Pearson rho equals 0.90, n equals 25, two-sided alpha equals 0.05, power greater than 0.99. Stabilization scan: approximately 50 minima per flux configuration and K variant, effect size delta V over V approximately 0.5, power greater than 0.85 with t-test (unequal variance, alpha equals 0.05). Total sample 2 Kähler metrics times 3 flux sectors times approximately 50 minima equals 300 potential evaluations.
limitations: GL12/D6 family is a single mirror-pair instance; generalization requires separate Picard-Fuchs analysis for other families, limiting empirical scope.
Numerical precision of Picard-Fuchs integration is limited by conditioning of the differential system near singular points; conifold regions may require specialized analytic continuation.
Flux superpotential W is chosen via ansatz; alternative flux choices may relax IIA constraints, conflating geometry with dynamics.
Stabilization minima are critical points of high-dimensional potential; metastability may introduce non-generic phenomena.
Swampland de Sitter conjecture is conjectural; violations do not disprove the mechanism, only phenomenological consistency.
Cross-validation via type IIB Picard-Fuchs requires independent computation; systematic error could obscure IIA-IIB alignment.
D6 symmetry reduces moduli space artificially; breaking to a generic subgroup would require solving higher-dimensional Picard-Fuchs systems with exponential cost.
experiment.requires_followup: No wet-lab confirmation is required. Follow-up computational task: extend the analysis from GL12/D6 to 2-3 additional mirror-pair families with different Hodge numbers or symmetries to assess generalizability of the IIA-IIB causal constraint. This would require repeating Picard-Fuchs integration and Kähler-metric reconstruction for each family, estimated at 2-3 weeks per family. Additionally, analyze whether complex-structure stabilization (via fixing W_flux minima) exhibits a predictable feedback on the Kähler moduli space geometry, as predicted by the mechanism.

hypotheses.source_question: Does the microscopic origin of F-term uplift mechanisms (anti-D3 backreaction, gaugino condensation corrections) causally determine which uplifting-term constructions are dynamically viable in a given moduli stabilization scenario, and conversely, does the requirement for a stable uplifting term constrain the allowed F-term contributions?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that the microscopic F-term uplift mechanism (anti-D3 backreaction or gaugino condensation) causally determines the functional form and stability of the effective uplifting potential, and that this constraint rules out a measurable fraction (≥30%) of phenomenologically proposed uplifting-term constructions as dynamically inconsistent with the moduli-stabilization locus in LVS scenarios.
hypotheses.mechanism: F-term sources (anti-D3 branes or gaugino condensation) generate corrections to the superpotential W and Kähler potential K that propagate through the supergravity scalar potential V = e^K(K^{ij̄}D_iWD̄_jW̄ + |W|²) evaluated at the complex-structure stabilization locus. These corrections determine the precise coefficient, power-law scaling, and curvature of the uplifting potential V_uplift. The effective uplifting term is not a free parametric addition but a constrained function of the F-term source strength, volume modulus, and stabilized complex-structure values. Conversely, requiring the uplifting potential to maintain positive semi-definite Hessian and satisfy swampland bounds imposes quantitative constraints on allowed F-term backreaction parameters.
hypotheses.prediction: For a concrete LVS scenario (e.g., GL12/D₆ CY3 with h¹¹=17, h²¹=20), computing the uplifting potential V_uplift(τ_s, z_i^stab) from anti-D3 backreaction will yield a coefficient that differs by ≥30% from the naive dimensional-analysis estimate, and imposing the condition ∂²V/∂τ_s² > 0 (Hessian stability) at the critical point will reduce the allowed parameter space by a factor of ≥2 compared to ad-hoc uplifting-term phenomenology. Additionally, at least one standard uplifting construction (e.g., constant-coefficient V_up = Λ⁴) will violate the swampland conjecture bound |∇V|/V ≥ c when derived self-consistently from F-term sources.
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If the computed uplifting potential V_uplift(τ_s, z_i^stab) from first-principles F-term backreaction yields a coefficient within ±10% of the naive parametric estimate, AND the Hessian eigenvalues remain positive definite across >80% of the parameter space allowed by tadpole and swampland constraints, AND all standard uplifting constructions satisfy |∇V|/V ≥ c at the critical point, then the F-term mechanism exerts negligible causal constraint on uplifting-term structure, and the gap between microscopic and phenomenological treatments is phenomenologically irrelevant.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: Explained variance in uplifting-potential coefficient: R² > 0.60 (F-term source variation accounts for >60% of V_uplift variance). Reduction in allowed parameter space: fold-change ≥ 2.0 (self-consistent F-term calculation shrinks viable region by factor of 2 or more). Swampland violation fraction: ≥ 30% of standard uplifting constructions fail |∇V|/V ≥ c test when backreaction is included.

experiment.approach: Implement a symbolic-numerical pipeline that (1) computes exact or asymptotic period integrals and their derivatives via the Picard-Fuchs system for the GL12/D₆ CY3, (2) evaluates the flux superpotential W and Kähler potential K at the complex-structure stabilization locus determined by ∂W/∂z_i = 0, (3) computes F-term backreaction corrections to W and K order-by-order in small parameters (1/V_CY, e^{-aτ_s}), (4) extracts the effective uplifting potential V_uplift by differentiating the scalar potential at fixed z_i^stab, (5) checks stability (Hessian) and swampland compliance, (6) compares against parametric uplifting-term phenomenology.
steps: Solve the GKZ Picard-Fuchs system numerically for the GL12/D₆ CY3 to obtain Π_a(z_1,...,z_5) and all derivatives ∂Π_a/∂z_i up to second order in a domain covering large-complex-structure, conifold, and stabilization limits.
Construct the flux superpotential W(z_i, τ^a) = G_a Π^a(z) + G_0 using representative flux integers (constrained by tadpole N_flux ≤ (2/3)h²¹ = 13-14).

Determine the complex-structure stabilization locus {z_i^stab(τ, G_a)} by solving ∂W/∂z_i = 0 symbolically or semi-analytically for small 1/V and express z_i^stab as functions of Kähler moduli τ_s and flux G_a.

Compute corrections to W at the locus: W_corrected = W + W_np^{(1)} + W_np^{(2)} where W_np^{(1)} ~ e^{-aτ_s} (gaugino condensation) and W_np^{(2)} contains anti-D3 backreaction (use leading-order result from literature, e.g., 2402.04089 Eq. 2.15).
Compute Kähler potential corrections K_corrected = K_classical + K_α' + K_flux + K_brane evaluated at z_i^stab, including 1/V and α'-flux corrections from standard LVS formulae.

Extract uplifting potential: V_uplift(τ_s) := [∂²V/∂τ_s²]_{z_i=z_i^stab, W_0 fixed} - V_0, where V is the full scalar potential and V_0 is the stabilized LVS value. Alternatively, use V_uplift = e^K(K^{ij̄}D_iW_npD̄_jW̄_np) with W_np the uplift contribution.
Measure V_uplift coefficient α: fit V_uplift ≈ α·e^{-2aτ_s}/V_CY^β near the stabilization locus and extract α, β numerically.
Compare α against naive estimate: α_naive ~ m₃/₂ M_p × (1/V) derived from dimensional analysis. Compute deviation Δα/α_naive.
Evaluate Hessian matrix H_ij = ∂²V/∂τ_i∂τ_j at the proposed de Sitter critical point across a grid of parameter values (G_a ∈ tadpole-allowed range, 1/V ∈ [0.01, 0.10]).

Compute swampland ratio |∇V|/V at the critical point for each parameter tuple. Test three standard uplifting constructions: (A) constant V_up = Λ⁴, (B) V_up ∝ e^{-aτ_s}, (C) V_up = e^{-aτ_s}/V² (anti-D3 ansatz). Count fraction violating |∇V|/V ≥ c (use c ≈ 0.1 from Ooguri-Vafa).
Perform one-way ANOVA or variance decomposition: regress V_uplift coefficient α against (1/V, 1/τ_s, G_a values, anti-D3 backreaction strength) to measure R² (explained variance).

Map viable parameter space: plot region of (G_a, anti-D3 strength, 1/V) satisfying (i) tadpole N_flux ≤ 14, (ii) Hessian pos. def., (iii) |∇V|/V ≥ 0.1. Compare total volume against parameter space with ad-hoc V_up (no backreaction constraint).
tools: Macaulay2 or Singular (GKZ system, Picard-Fuchs differential operators, toric variety computations)
Python + SymPy (symbolic period integral manipulation, W and K derivatives)
Mathematica or Julia (numerical root-finding for stabilization locus z_i^stab(τ, G_a), ODE solving for periods)
Public CY3 mirror database (Kreuzer-Skarke polytope 37 / GL12, h¹¹=17, h²¹=20 embedding data)
LVS analytic approximations (Bena-Grana-Halmagyi 0811.1225, Cicoli-Krippendorff-Murayama-Valandro-Zhang 1902.07649: K_Kähler = -2ln(V), K_cs from periods)
Anti-D3 backreaction model (from 2402.04089 or 2401.13567: numerical W_uplift formula or perturbative expansion)
SageMath or custom Python for stability analysis (eigenvalue decomposition, parameter sweep)
experiment.estimated_effort: 8–12 weeks: 2 weeks setting up GKZ system and period numerics, 2 weeks flux superpotential and stabilization locus, 2 weeks K-potential assembly and backreaction, 2 weeks V_uplift extraction and Hessian, 2 weeks swampland tests and parameter mapping.
experiment.data_requirements: Kreuzer-Skarke polytope data for GL12/D₆ (public KS list); representative flux G_a integers (typically 20–50 integer tuples for tadpole check); anti-D3 backreaction coefficients from literature (order-1 numbers × powers of e^{-aτ_s}); literature values for α', flux, and string-loop corrections to K and W.
experiment.expected_positive: Computed V_uplift coefficient α shows ≥30% deviation from naive estimate, meaning F-term backreaction is non-trivial. Hessian remains positive-definite over only ≤50% of (G_a, backreaction strength) space, constraining viable uplifts. ≥30% of standard phenomenological uplifting constructions violate swampland bound |∇V|/V ≥ 0.1 when backreaction is self-consistently included. Variance decomposition yields R² ≥ 0.60, confirming F-term source dominates V_uplift structure.
experiment.expected_negative: If V_uplift coefficient α is within ±10% of dimensional-analysis estimate, Hessian eigenvalues remain positive across >80% of parameter space, and <20% of constructions violate swampland bounds, then F-term effects are sub-dominant corrections and do not causally constrain uplifting-term phenomenology. The gap closes because microscopic and phenomenological treatments agree quantitatively.
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: The F-term uplift mechanism (anti-D3, gaugino condensation) produces an uplifting potential whose leading coefficient and stability properties are independent of (or only weakly dependent on) the microscopic F-term source structure and backreaction strength. Uplifting-term constructions are viable independently of F-term constraints.
experiment.statistical_test: One-way ANOVA (R² ≥ 0.60 for F-term source variance contribution); chi-square test on swampland violation counts (≥30% of constructions fail, exact binomial test at α=0.05); Hessian eigenvalue sign test across parameter grid (reject H₀ if >50% of grid points have ≤1 negative eigenvalue, indicating instability). For each test, α=0.05 two-sided.
experiment.minimum_detectable_effect: R² > 0.60 (F-term source explains >60% of V_uplift variance, Cohen's f² ≈ 1.5, large effect); fold-change ≥ 2.0 in allowed parameter space (reduction by factor 2 is scientifically meaningful in moduli space); swampland violation ≥ 30% (binomial test: n=3 standard constructions, ≥1 failure, p=0.33 under null, binomial p-value ≈ 0.037 against uniform null). For continuous parameters (V_uplift coefficient, Hessian eigenvalues), absolute deviation ≥ 30% from baseline constitutes meaningful constraint.
experiment.statistical_power_notes: Computational experiment: no sample size per se. Instead, convergence criterion: period integral and stabilization locus computed to ≥6 significant figures (asymptotic error <1e-6 relative), Hessian eigenvalues stable across ≥100 evenly-spaced grid points in (G_a, backreaction strength, 1/V) parameter space. Variance decomposition: regress V_uplift against 4–5 F-term-source variables; with 100+ parameter tuples, R² > 0.60 is detectable with >90% statistical power. Swampland test: 3 constructions × ~30 parameter tuples = 90 independent checks; binomial test for ≥30% violation rate has power >85% to reject uniform null at α=0.05.
limitations: LVS regime assumes large volume V ≫ 1 and weak string coupling; backreaction expansion only valid in this limit, so results may not hold in intermediate-coupling or small-volume regimes.
Picard-Fuchs system solved numerically in a finite domain (large-complex-structure, conifold neighborhoods); extrapolation to distant regions in moduli space is unreliable.

Anti-D3 backreaction model taken from literature (assumed accurate); if true backreaction form differs significantly, uplifting-potential structure will change. Cross-validation against independent microscopic sources (e.g., string-loop amplitudes) is limited by computational scope.
GL12/D₆ CY3 is a single example; generalization to other CY3 with different (h¹¹, h²¹, symmetries) requires re-running pipeline, limiting scope.
Swampland conjecture (|∇V|/V ≥ c) is itself contested in literature; threshold c ≈ 0.1 is indicative, not definitive. Results are sensitive to choice of c.
Does not address whether the resulting de Sitter vacuum is truly metastable (requires real-time decay computation, beyond scope); stability analysis is purely classical.
experiment.requires_followup: Wet-lab (microscopic) validation: compute anti-D3 backreaction via (i) holomorphic curve integrals on the CY3 (topological string amplitude calculations), (ii) D-brane instanton sums, or (iii) direct 11D supergravity near-brane asymptotics. These would verify or refute the anti-D3 form used in the computational step. Alternatively, extract anti-D3 backreaction from first-principles string-theory scattering amplitudes (multi-loop string worldsheet). Such a first-principles calculation would close the loop between microscopic F-term and phenomenological uplifting potential, converting this computational study from a phenomenological map into a rigorous microscopic derivation.

hypotheses.source_question: Does type IIA compactification on CY3 with RR fluxes and D-brane tadpoles impose non-trivial constraints on the period integral structure and moduli stabilization locus that differ qualitatively from type IIB, specifically: do IIA flux superpotentials derived from RR tadpole quantization conditions causally determine accessible regions of complex-structure moduli space?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that type IIA RR-flux tadpole quantization constraints causally restrict the accessible complex-structure moduli space by eliminating period integral solutions that do not simultaneously satisfy both D-brane charge quantization and flux-induced superpotential stabilization, thereby reducing the dimension of the moduli stabilization locus relative to type IIB by a factor determined by the rank of the K-theory tadpole matrix.
hypotheses.mechanism: In type IIA compactifications, RR fluxes couple directly to D-brane sources via K-theory charge quantization: N_RR ∈ Λ_{RR} ⊂ H^*(CY, ℤ). The IIA flux superpotential W_IIA = ∫(G_RR ∧ Ω) becomes a constrained functional over period space because each allowed flux configuration must simultaneously satisfy: (1) tadpole cancellation N_IIA^{(0,2)} + ∑_i q_i^{(0,2)} = 0 and (2) anomaly cancellation in the duality frame. In type IIB, such constraints are absent: RR fluxes couple via even cohomology without D-brane sourcing. The K-theory quantization of IIA thus acts as a filter operator P on the space of period integral solutions Π_a(z), effectively partitioning moduli space into allowed {z ∈ M_cs : P(Π(z)) = 0} and forbidden regions. This partition reduces dim(M_cs^{stab}) relative to IIB by codim(ker P), typically 1–3 for generic CY3.
hypotheses.prediction: For a mirror pair (quintic ↔ mirror), the set of simultaneous solutions to (1) IIA tadpole equations and (2) stabilization locus (∂W_IIA/∂z_i = 0) will form a 3–5 dimensional subvariety of the 20-dimensional complex-structure moduli space, while the IIB tadpole-free stabilization locus for equivalent flux data spans 6–8 dimensions; equivalently, the IIA constraint codimension will be ≥1.5-fold higher than IIB, measurable as (dim M_IIA^{stab})/(dim M_IIB^{stab}) < 0.7.
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If numerical evaluation shows that (a) the dimension of the IIA flux stabilization locus exceeds that of IIB by >1.2×, OR (b) the K-theory tadpole constraints do not eliminate any period integral solutions (i.e., ker P = ∅ or codim(ker P) = 0 for >95% of random flux configurations sampled), OR (c) IIA and IIB stabilization loci coincide at all tested special points (large-cs, conifold, large-volume limits), then the hypothesis is refuted. Specifically: if (dim M_IIA^{stab})/(dim M_IIB^{stab}) > 0.85 across ≥3 mirror pairs, reject the hypothesis.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: Codimension of IIA tadpole constraint >1 (i.e., >2 independent linear constraints on period space), OR reduction in stabilizable moduli space dimension by ≥2 dimensions (e.g., 8→5 or 7→4), OR measurable exclusion of ≥30% of flux configurations that would stabilize in IIB case. Quantitatively: Fraction_IIA_excluded / Fraction_IIB_unconstrained > 1.4.

experiment.approach: Construct explicit Picard-Fuchs differential systems for a concrete mirror pair (quintic ↔ mirror quintic) in both IIA and IIB frames. Numerically solve the GKZ systems near special points (large-cs, conifold limits); impose IIA tadpole quantization constraints as polynomial equations on periods; enumerate flux configurations compatible with both stabilization and tadpole constraints; compare dimension and volume of allowed moduli regions between IIA and IIB using Monte Carlo sampling and constraint-rank analysis.
steps: Step 1: Compute the GKZ operators L_i for both quintic and mirror quintic using the GLSM charge matrix (e.g., [1,1,1,1,1,–5] for quintic in ℂℙ⁴). Validate against known period integrals from Aspinwall-Morrison.

Step 2: Solve the Picard-Fuchs system L_i Π_a(z) = 0 numerically at a grid of 500–1000 points in the 20-dimensional complex-structure moduli space (using monodromy-invariant bases and connection matrices near conifold z = 1, large-cs z → ∞).

Step 3: Construct the IIA flux superpotential W_IIA(z; {N_RR}) = ∑_a N_a^{IIA} Π_a(z) for flux quanta N_a ∈ ℤ constrained by K-theory tadpole equations (e.g., N_{(0,2)} = χ/24 for an orbifold, or explicit K-theory charge quantization from Freed-Moore). For each of ~1000 random flux choices, compute ∂W_IIA/∂z_i and identify critical points.

Step 4: Enforce tadpole constraint: retain only solutions {z, {N_RR}} satisfying both (a) ∂W_IIA/∂z_i = 0 and (b) K-theory tadpole matching (e.g., N_{RR}^{(0,2)} + q_D^{(0,2)} = 0 where q_D are D-brane charges). Record the dimension and volume of this constrained subvariety.
Step 5: Repeat Step 4 for IIB using even-dimensional fluxes with no K-theory constraint, allowing unconstrained flux quantization across the same moduli grid.

Step 6: Compare: compute dim(M_IIA^{stab}) and dim(M_IIB^{stab}) via principal component analysis (PCA) on the solution sets. Quantify the fraction of random flux configurations that stabilize in IIA vs. IIB. Compute the effective codimension of the IIA tadpole constraint via rank of the constraint Jacobian.
Step 7: Validate the mirror map: verify that IIA periods at special points match IIB periods under z_IIA ↔ t_IIB (mirror coordinates) to confirm duality; check for breaking.
Step 8: Repeat Steps 1–7 for 2 additional mirror pairs (e.g., degree-8 sextic hypersurface in ℂℚ(1,1,2,2,2), and a K3×T² fibration proxy) to test robustness of the codimension reduction.
tools: Magma/Macaulay2: GKZ differential operator computation, polynomial constraint solving
SageMath or Mathematica: numerical ODE solver for Picard-Fuchs systems (monodromy-adaptive stepping)
CYToolkit / cdd/lrs: polytope analysis for GKZ lattice points and toric ambient space
Public CY databases: CICY, Kreuzer-Skarke (KS) database mirror pairs; confirmed period data (Aspinwall-Morrison, Hosono-Lian-Yau)
NumPy/SciPy: Monte Carlo flux sampling (uniform or Metropolis on flux space), PCA for dimension reduction, constraint Jacobian rank computation
GAP or Sage: K-theory computation via Chern classes and Atiyah-Hirzebruch spectral sequence (if needed for explicit tadpole quantization)
experiment.estimated_effort: 8–12 weeks compute (parallelizable: 2 weeks single-core baseline, 3–5 days with HPC cluster for 3 mirror pairs × 10 restart points × 1000 flux samples each). Code development: 4 weeks.
experiment.data_requirements: Public period integral tables (Aspinwall-Morrison, CICY, Kreuzer-Skarke), GKZ systems from published papers (e.g., Hosono et al.), toric geometry data from polytope databases. Total data size: ~100 MB. Computing resources: 500–2000 CPU-hours.
experiment.expected_positive: Numerical results show (dim M_IIA^{stab})/(dim M_IIB^{stab}) ≈ 0.6–0.7 across 3 mirror pairs; K-theory tadpole constraints eliminate >40% of flux configurations that would classically stabilize in IIB; constraint Jacobian rank ≥3 at ≥80% of tested moduli points; IIA and IIB stabilization loci diverge near conifold (measured by Hausdorff distance >1 in normalized moduli space). Mirror map holds to machine precision in unconstrained directions but breaks in constrained directions (residual >10⁻³).
experiment.expected_negative: If (dim M_IIA^{stab})/(dim M_IIB^{stab}) > 0.85; or K-theory constraints have rank 0–1 (eliminate <20% of configurations); or IIA and IIB stabilization loci coincide to within numerical error; or the computed constrained dimension does not scale consistently across different mirror pairs. Any of these would indicate that IIA tadpole constraints are either vacuous or act globally without fine-grained moduli filtering.
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: Type IIA D-brane tadpole quantization does not causally restrict the accessible complex-structure moduli space; equivalently, the set of flux stabilization solutions {z ∈ M_cs : ∂W_IIA/∂z_i = 0} has the same dimension and volume as the IIB case, and the K-theory constraint rank is zero (trivial on periods).
experiment.statistical_test: Primary: rank-deficiency test on the constraint Jacobian ∂(W_IIA, Tadpole equations)/∂z via singular-value decomposition (SVD); null hypothesis: rank < 2 (no effective constraint). Secondary: chi-squared test on the fraction of stabilizable flux configurations: H₀: f_IIA = f_IIB (test via ~1000 random flux samples per frame). Tertiary: Hausdorff distance test comparing solution sets: H₀: d_H(M_IIA^{stab}, M_IIB^{stab}) < 0.1 × diam(M_cs). Reject H₀ at α = 0.05 if SVD rank ≥3 with singular-value gap >2×, or f_IIA < 0.6 × f_IIB with p < 0.05 (binomial test), or d_H > 0.2 × diam(M_cs).
experiment.minimum_detectable_effect: Codimension of IIA constraint ≥1.5 (i.e., ≥3 independent polynomial constraints on 20-dimensional moduli space with non-zero Jacobian). Equivalently: dim(M_IIA^{stab}) < 0.7 × dim(M_IIB^{stab}), or fraction_stabilizable_IIA / fraction_stabilizable_IIB < 0.65. SVD rank of constraint Jacobian ≥2 with condition number <100 (well-conditioned constraint).
experiment.statistical_power_notes: Sample size: n_flux = 1000 random flux configurations per frame (IIA, IIB). Assumed effect size: codimension reduction of 2 dimensions out of 20 (effect size d ≈ 0.3 on normalized moduli space). Power calculation: with n=1000, two-sided rank test α=0.05, we achieve power >0.9 to detect codimension ≥1.5 assuming SNR (signal-to-noise ratio) >3 on constraint magnitude. For dimension reduction: PCA will stabilize to ±0.5 dimensions with n=1000 samples. Convergence criterion (for ODE solving): relative tolerance 10⁻⁸ on Picard-Fuchs system; period accuracy ≈ 1 part in 10⁷ (validated against published values).
limitations: Computational cost limits analysis to 3 mirror pairs; results may not generalize to all CY3 with h²¹ > 20.
Tadpole constraint formulation relies on assumed K-theory quantization rule (Freed-Moore); alternative quantization conventions could alter effective codimension.
Numerical period integration near conifold and large-cs is ill-conditioned; monodromy around singular loci must be tracked explicitly, introducing systematic error ~10⁻⁵.
IIA and IIB comparison assumes exact mirror symmetry; quantum corrections (world-sheet instanton) and α' effects not included, which may break symmetry at O(1) level.

Flux stabilization locus is generically a solution set of nonlinear polynomial equations; dimension is defined as topological dimension of connected components, which may be fragmented or empty for some flux choices.
D-brane backreaction and metric deformation are neglected; only linear constraints from tadpole matching are imposed.
experiment.requires_followup: Yes: (1) Construct explicit D-brane configurations (e.g., fractional branes or brane-antibrane pairs) on a mirror Calabi-Yau and verify that the computed K-theory charges match the imposed tadpole constraints. (2) Solve the full moduli-dependent supergravity equations (Einstein + scalar field equations) at representative stabilization loci in both IIA and IIB to confirm that the reduced-dimension moduli subspace is indeed dynamically favored. (3) Compute higher-derivative corrections (α', gs) and check whether they preserve or break the IIA/IIB distinction at the constraint level. (4) If IIA constraint is confirmed, use it to optimize Monte Carlo flux searches for metastable de Sitter vacua in IIA; predict observable uplift mass hierarchy and compare to KKLT/LVS benchmarks.

hypotheses.source_question: How do O3/O7-plane tadpole constraints quantitatively restrict the complex-structure moduli stabilization locus and the achievable superpotential W(z_i) in type IIB orientifolds, and does this constraint propagate to limit the Kähler moduli subspace via the mirror map?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that O3/O7-plane fixed-point loci create algebraic singularities or monodromy discontinuities in the period-integral domain of type IIB orientifolds, and that these singularities restrict the complex-structure stabilization locus to a lower-dimensional sub-variety, which in turn projects via the mirror map to reduce the feasible Kähler moduli space and enforce the hierarchy constraints of LVS (exponentially large volume) or exclude KKLT-type solutions.
hypotheses.mechanism: O-plane orientifold involution acts on the Calabi-Yau 3-fold by fixing a codimension-3 locus (O3 at points, O7 on divisors). This involution induces a decomposition of the period domain: periods of even/odd parity under the involution satisfy complementary Picard-Fuchs sub-systems. As the complex-structure moduli z_i approach the O-plane fixed locus, the intersection matrix of vanishing cycles acquires zero eigenvalues, causing monodromy and branch-point singularities in Π_a(z). Stabilization equations ∂W/∂z_i = 0 (with W = G_a Π^a + F_a ∂Π^a/∂τ) cannot be simultaneously satisfied near such singularities because gradients diverge. The mirror map t^a = ∂F/∂X^a then maps this reduced complex-structure stabilization locus to a restricted Kähler subspace, forbidding certain (τ_s, W_0) hierarchies and explaining why KKLT requires W_0 << 1 or LVS requires exponentially large V.
hypotheses.prediction: For the GL=12/D₆ orientifold (h¹¹=17, h²¹=20), computation of the 20-dimensional period domain restricted to the 5-dimensional D₆-invariant subspace will reveal that the O3/O7 fixed-point locus, when pulled back to complex-structure space, defines a codimension-≥1 algebraic variety V_O. The stabilization locus L_stab (solution set of ∂W/∂z_i = 0) will be measured to have codimension ≥1 relative to V_O: i.e., dim(L_stab ∩ ℂ^5) ≤ 2 when dim(V_O) ≤ 3, and L_stab will exhibit monodromy (period sheet multiplicity > 1) at ≥2 independent monodromy points in V_O. The projection of L_stab via the mirror map will exclude ≥30% of the (τ_s, W_0) parameter space nominally allowed by the tadpole conjecture alone (N_flux ≤ 2/3 h²¹ ≈ 13.3).
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If numerical resolution of the GKZ system for GL=12/D₆ shows that (i) the O3/O7 fixed-point variety V_O has codimension ≥4 in the 5-dimensional D₆-invariant subspace, OR (ii) the intersection L_stab ∩ V_O is isolated (0-dimensional, not a continuous locus), OR (iii) the period integrals Π_a(z) are analytic (no monodromy, no branch points) along all geodesics within V_O, OR (iv) the mirror-map projection of L_stab covers ≥95% of the (τ_s, W_0) domain allowed by the tadpole bound, then the hypothesis is refuted: O-plane geometry does not dynamically constrain stabilization.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: Codimension of V_O in complex-structure space ≥1 (i.e., V_O has measure zero but is a genuine algebraic subvariety, not generic); monodromy multiplicity ≥2 at ≥2 distinct points; explained variance in (τ_s, W_0) exclusion ≥30% (i.e., the O-plane constraint removes a connected region of volume ≥0.3 × V_nominal).

experiment.approach: Computationally resolve the GKZ differential system for the GL=12/D₆ orientifold in the 5-dimensional D₆-invariant subspace; construct numerical period integrals Π_a(z) as functions of moduli; identify the O3/O7 fixed-point locus as an algebraic variety by solving the orientifold involution equations; trace monodromy and discontinuities in periods along geodesics intersecting this locus; solve the stabilization equations ∂W/∂z_i = 0 on the period domain and measure the dimension and monodromy structure of the solution locus; apply the mirror map to project stabilization solutions to Kähler moduli space and quantify the excluded region in (τ_s, W_0) parameter space.
steps: Construct the toric polytope and GLSM charge matrix (Q-matrix) for GL=12/D₆ from the Kreuzer-Skarke database; verify h¹¹=17, h²¹=20, and D₆ symmetry (index 37).
Compute the GKZ system {L_i} of differential operators acting on period integrals, reducing to the 5-dimensional D₆-invariant subspace using representation theory (D₆ characters).

Solve the Picard-Fuchs equations numerically along a grid in the 5-dimensional moduli space z ∈ ℂ^5 using monodromy matrices and analytic continuation. Store monodromy multiplicity at each lattice point.

Define the O3/O7 fixed-point variety V_O by solving the involution equations (symplectic automorphism of H³(X,ℤ) preserving the intersection form); compute V_O as the zero locus of invariant polynomial equations in the 5 moduli.

Measure the algebraic dimension and codimension of V_O in ℂ^5 using Gröbner basis methods or singularity resolution. Check for branch-point singularities in Π_a(z) along hyperplanes transverse to V_O.

Construct the superpotential W(z) = G_a Π^a(z) + F_a (∂Π^a/∂τ)/Π^a (Gukov-Vafa form) with representative flux quantum numbers (G_a, F_a) from the tadpole bound; solve ∂W/∂z_i = 0 numerically using homotopy continuation.

Measure the dimension and monodromy multiplicity of the stabilization locus L_stab (solution set); count the number of connected components and isolated points in L_stab; classify monodromy around L_stab ∩ V_O.

Apply the mirror map t^a = ∂F/∂X^a (relating complex-structure moduli to Kähler moduli via Hodge-diamond duality) to project L_stab into (τ_s, W_0) space; compute the volume of the excluded region (parameter space nominally allowed by tadpole but forbidden by O-plane geometry).

Cross-validate against known KKLT and LVS solutions: verify that excluded (τ_s, W_0) regions include W_0 ~ O(1) or small-volume regimes, and that allowed regions reproduce W_0 << 1 or exponentially large V.
Repeat for ≥2 other type IIB orientifold models (e.g., K3 × K3 with O3/O7, or another Calabi-Yau from KS database with high symmetry) to assess robustness of the mechanism.
tools: Macaulay2 or Singular (Gröbner basis, singularity analysis, codimension computation)
magma or gap (group representation theory, D₆ character decomposition)
phcpack or Bertini (homotopy continuation for polynomial system solving)
mpmath or SageMath (high-precision numerical integration of differential systems)
custom Python/Julia code (monodromy tracking, branch-cut detection, mirror-map inversion)
Kreuzer-Skarke database (polytope data for GL=12/D₆ and comparison models)
Literature GKZ systems (for models with known period integrals to validate numerical solver)
experiment.estimated_effort: 8–12 weeks: 2 weeks polytope setup + GKZ derivation; 3 weeks Picard-Fuchs solver + monodromy tracking; 2 weeks O-plane locus resolution; 2 weeks stabilization solving + mirror-map projection; 1–2 weeks validation + cross-model testing.
experiment.data_requirements: Kreuzer-Skarke database polytope file for GL=12/D₆ (publicly available); representative flux quantum numbers from literature (tadpole bound N_flux ≤ 13.3); known KKLT/LVS solutions for GL=12/D₆ (if available in arXiv preprints) for cross-validation; optionally, precomputed GKZ systems from prior string-theory publications.
experiment.expected_positive: GKZ resolution yields period integrals with ≥2 monodromy points in V_O (codimension ≥1 in ℂ^5); stabilization locus L_stab has codimension ≥1 relative to the full moduli space and exhibits monodromy multiplicity >1 along V_O; mirror-map projection excludes ≥30% of the (τ_s, W_0) parameter region, with excluded region correlated to KKLT-forbidden hierarchies (W_0 ~ O(1)) and LVS-allowed hierarchies (W_0 << 1, V >> 1).
experiment.expected_negative: V_O has codimension ≥4 (measure zero but 'generic'); Π_a(z) are analytic (no monodromy, no branch singularities) within V_O; L_stab is 0-dimensional (isolated points, not a locus) or does not intersect V_O; mirror-map projection of L_stab covers ≥95% of the tadpole-allowed (τ_s, W_0) region; no systematic exclusion of W_0 ~ O(1) or small-V regimes.
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: The O3/O7-plane fixed-point variety V_O is a generic (codimension-≥4) locus in the complex-structure moduli space that induces no discontinuities in period integrals; the stabilization locus L_stab is determined solely by the flux superpotential topology (tadpole bound and flux quantum numbers) and is independent of O-plane geometry; the mirror-map projection does not constrain Kähler moduli beyond the tadpole bound.
experiment.statistical_test: Topological/algebraic: codimension of V_O computed via Gröbner basis dimension algorithm (deterministic); monodromy multiplicity via eigenvalue count of monodromy matrix M around L_stab ∩ V_O (exact integer, threshold ≥2); volume exclusion via numerical integration over (τ_s, W_0) grid before and after O-plane constraint (binomial test or ratio test; threshold ≥30% exclusion, one-sided, confidence 95%). For monodromy presence, any eigenvalue of M outside the unit circle or with phase discontinuity >π definitively signals monodromy (threshold-free).
experiment.minimum_detectable_effect: Codimension ≥1 (V_O is a proper subvariety, not generic); monodromy multiplicity ≥2 (at least one eigenvalue of M with |λ| ≠ 1 or non-trivial phase); volume exclusion ≥30% of the tadpole-allowed region in (τ_s, W_0) parameter space (measurable as ratio of pre- and post-constraint volumes).
experiment.statistical_power_notes: Computational experiment is deterministic: Gröbner basis computation and monodromy eigenvalue counting are exact algebraic operations, not statistical. No sample size or power calculation applies. Convergence criterion for numerical integration of Π_a(z): absolute error <10⁻⁸ (relative error <10⁻⁶ for superpotential W) using adaptive quadrature; homotopy continuation tracks all complex solutions to ∂W/∂z_i = 0 with certified path tracking (no spurious solutions). Grid resolution in (τ_s, W_0): ≥500 × 500 points to ensure volume exclusion ratio is stable to <±2%.
limitations: GL=12/D₆ model may not be representative of all type IIB orientifolds; cross-model validation (≥2 additional Calabi-Yau geometries) is necessary but computationally expensive.

GKZ system numerical solver assumes the periods are not pathological (e.g., logarithmic singularities); verification that the solver correctly handles branch-point monodromy requires cross-check against known analytic period formulas (rare for CY3).

O-plane fixed-point variety V_O is defined via involution action on H³(X,ℤ); this requires correct assignment of the orientifold involution, which may have multiple topologically-distinct choices per model (type O3, O5, O7, O9); only the D₆-equivariant involution is considered here.

Mirror map t^a = ∂F/∂X^a requires computation of the prepotential F on the mirror family (K3 × K3 or dual Calabi-Yau); if the mirror is singular or high-dimensional, F may be unknown and the projection to Kähler moduli cannot be completed.
KKLT/LVS solutions are rare in the literature for the GL=12/D₆ model; cross-validation relies on comparing excluded hierarchies to known solutions in nearby models, introducing indirect inference.

Monodromy multiplicity and branch-point singularities are detected numerically; a rigorous algebraic certificate (via resolution of singularities or singularity theory) would strengthen the conclusion but is not computationally feasible for high-dimensional spaces.
experiment.requires_followup: No immediate wet-lab requirement. However, if the computation confirms that O-plane geometry restricts stabilization, the next step would be to explicitly construct a type IIB flux compactification (via numerical gluing of D-brane and flux data) that realizes the predicted (τ_s, W_0) hierarchy and check consistency with 10-dimensional supergravity equations of motion. This would require solving the coupled Einstein + Dilaton + Flux equations, typically done via numerical relativity or elliptic PDE solvers (computational proxy: Singular or Macaulay2 with numerical refinement); a true wet-lab analog (direct experimental geometry measurement) does not exist, as CY3 compactification is a mathematical structure.

hypotheses.source_question: Does the choice of orientifold involution (O3/O7 planes) in type IIB compactification fundamentally alter the structure of the Picard-Fuchs differential system governing period integrals, and if so, can this constraint be inverted to predict allowed orientifold choices from the holomorphic geometry of the Calabi-Yau 3-fold alone?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that orientifold involutions in type IIB compactifications causally reduce the rank and structure of the Picard-Fuchs differential system governing complex-structure periods by enforcing symmetry constraints on the GKZ lattice, such that the number of independent period integrals shrinks by a factor proportional to |Involution| and the degree of the GKZ operators decreases measurably.
hypotheses.mechanism: Orientifold involutions act on the toric ambient space as lattice automorphisms, reducing the rank of the charge matrix Q (the GLSM data) and projecting out non-invariant generators. This lattice reduction causes the GKZ differential operators L_i to factorize or decouple into sub-systems that are closed under the involution action. Consequently, periods Π_a(z) that are odd under the involution become redundant, and only the involution-even periods appear in the type IIB physical data (flux superpotential, mirror map). The number of independent operators shrinks from h^{2,1} to h^{2,1}_+ = dim(H^{2,1}(CY)^+_involution), and operator degree decreases because the reduced charge matrix has smaller rank.
hypotheses.prediction: For the GL=12/D_6 CY3 (h^{2,1}=20, D_6 involution of order 2), the GKZ system computed from the full polytope (20 generators) will reduce under D_6 symmetry projection to a sub-system with at most 5 independent differential operators of lower degree, matching the dimension of the D_6-invariant moduli subspace. Quantitatively: the number of independent period integrals will decrease by ≥75% (from 20 to ≤5), and the maximum degree of the PF operators will decrease by ≥30% relative to the full system.
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If explicit computation of the full GKZ system for GL=12 and independent computation of the D_6-invariant reduction show that (i) the number of independent periods does NOT drop below 10, or (ii) the maximum operator degree in the invariant sub-system equals that of the full system, or (iii) the D_6-invariant period space does not close under the full PF differential action, then the hypothesis is refuted.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: ≥2-fold reduction in number of independent period integrals (from 20 to ≤10); or ≥30% reduction in characteristic degree of GKZ operators; or existence of a basis of periods Π_+^a(z_+) such that ∂Π_+/∂z_i ∈ span(Π_+) and PF operators in z_+ coordinates have rank ≤ 5.

experiment.approach: Compute the GKZ differential system for complex-structure periods on the GL=12/D_6 Calabi-Yau 3-fold from first principles using the toric polytope, then independently extract the D_6-invariant sub-system by applying symmetry reduction. Compare operator rank, degree, and the dimension of the period space in each case to quantify the causal reduction.
steps: Step 1: Obtain the full convex polytope lattice for GL=12 (h^{2,1}=20 dimensional) from the Kreuzer-Skarke database or published sources (e.g. Aspinwall-Morrison tables). Construct the GLSM charge matrix Q ∈ ℤ^{1 × 27} (26 generators + 1 relation).

Step 2: Compute the full GKZ system of differential operators L_i(θ) using standard algorithms (e.g. gfan / Macaulay2 / Singular GKZ module). Extract: (a) number of independent operators n_full, (b) characteristic degree d_full, (c) rank of the operator module.

Step 3: Identify the D_6 involution action on the polytope generators (known from symmetry structure: D_6 has order 2 acting via coordinate permutations / sign flips on the ambient space). Decompose polytope generators into D_6-orbits.
Step 4: Restrict the charge matrix Q to D_6-invariant generators only, producing Q_red. Recompute the GKZ system for the reduced system: extract n_red, d_red, and rank.

Step 5: Compute the mirror map coordinates z → z_+(z) restricted to the D_6-invariant locus. Verify that periods Π_+(z_+) satisfy the reduced PF system and that the moduli space closes: dim(H^{2,1}_+) = 5.
Step 6: For each PF operator, compute its action on period integrals before and after reduction. Measure how many linearly independent period derivatives are generated (closure test).

Step 7: Tabulate: number of operators, degrees, codimension of invariant moduli, and verify that the involution-odd periods are indeed not required for type IIB physical observables (flux superpotential, Yukawa couplings).
Step 8: Repeat Steps 1–7 for a second example (e.g. a CY3 with h^{2,1}=8 and an involution of order 3 or 2, if available in literature) to validate generality.
tools: Macaulay2 / Singular with GKZ module package
gfan (Gröbner fan and GKZ systems)
Kreuzer-Skarke CY3 database query tools (e.g. http://hep.itp.tuwien.ac.at/~kreuzer/CY/)
Custom Python/SageMath script to: (i) parse polytope; (ii) apply involution action; (iii) compute reduced charge matrix; (iv) orchestrate symbolic algebra calls
Published GL=12 symmetry data (Aspinwall, Candelas, or Schüler databases)
Mirror symmetry map tools (e.g. PALP or CY3 databases with mirror coordinates)
experiment.estimated_effort: 3–4 weeks compute time (including symbolic algebra bottlenecks for GKZ computation on 20-dimensional system); mostly CPU-bound, manageable on shared cluster or high-end workstation.
experiment.data_requirements: GL=12 polytope and symmetry action (publicly available); access to GKZ symbolic algebra engines; no proprietary data needed. Estimated input data: ~1 MB (polytope generators + involution matrix).
experiment.expected_positive: The reduced GKZ system (n_red ≤ 5, d_red ≤ d_full - 2) accurately reproduces all D_6-invariant periods and satisfies closure under PF operators. The number of independent moduli on the D_6-invariant locus equals 5, confirming that complex-structure moduli reduction is *caused* by the involution's lattice action, not merely correlated.
experiment.expected_negative: The number of independent operators in the reduced system remains ≥ 10 (no significant reduction), or the reduced operator set does not close under differentiation on the invariant moduli space, or independent calculation of D_6-invariant periods via other methods (e.g. direct integration, series expansions) disagrees with the GKZ predictions.
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: The orientifold involution does not causally constrain the GKZ differential system. Equivalently, the full set of 20 period integrals remains independent on the D_6-invariant moduli subspace, and the GKZ operators governing them do not factorize or decouple when restricted to invariant combinations.
experiment.statistical_test: Deterministic algebraic comparison (not a statistical test): (i) Rank of the reduced versus full GKZ operator module via Smith normal form or similar; (ii) Dimension of the invariant moduli subspace via symmetric polynomial invariants; (iii) Closure test: compute ∂Π_+^a/∂z_i for all i and verify all results lie in span(Π_+). If any step fails, H₀ cannot be rejected.
experiment.minimum_detectable_effect: ≥2-fold decrease in effective operator rank (from ~20 to ≤10); OR degree of characteristic polynomial of the reduced system is ≥30% lower than the full system; OR explicit construction of 15+ periods that vanish identically on the invariant locus (codimension of non-invariant subspace ≥ 15).
experiment.statistical_power_notes: Not applicable (deterministic algebraic computation). Convergence criterion: GKZ computation must run to completion with full rank output; comparison of rank before/after reduction is exact, not probabilistic. Success ≡ symbolic verification that rank(Q_red) < rank(Q_full) and all invariant-reduced periods satisfy the lower-rank PF system without error.
limitations: Computation is specific to GL=12 as a proof-of-concept; generalization to all involution types requires sampling additional CY3s, which is resource-intensive.
The hypothesis predicts *causal* reduction but does not uniquely specify the involution from the period structure alone (inverse problem remains underdetermined).
Does not address which involution choices lead to consistent type IIB flux stabilization (KKLT, LVS, etc.); only addresses GKZ structure.
Assumes the involution acts linearly on the polytope; non-linear, non-effective involutions would require separate analysis.
GKZ computation for 20-dimensional moduli space is near current computational limits; may face numerical/symbolic bottlenecks depending on operator degree.
experiment.requires_followup: After confirming GKZ structure reduction computationally: (1) Compute the flux superpotential W(z_+) numerically using the reduced period integrals and verify that non-invariant periods do not appear in physical observables (Yukawa couplings, flux quanta). (2) Solve the moduli stabilization equations ∂W/∂z_i = 0 on the D_6-invariant locus and check that solutions are consistent with KKLT or LVS expectations. (3) Perform explicit mirror-curve calculations or D-brane wrapping numbers to independently validate the period reduction. These are all computational but involve more specialized physics input.

hypotheses.source_question: Does the mirror symmetry of Schoen Calabi-Yau threefolds (h¹¹=h²¹=12, self-mirror) enable closed-form computation of type IIA symplectic invariants (prepotential F, Yukawa couplings) that directly constrain type IIB period integrals and moduli stabilization via mirror duality?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that the type IIA prepotential F computed from Gromov-Witten invariants on the Schoen threefold causally determines the type IIB period integrals Π_a via the mirror map t^a = ∂F/∂X^a, such that complex-structure stabilization loci are uniquely constrained by the Kähler geometry encoded in F, manifesting as ≥90% agreement in Yukawa coupling predictions κ_{abc} between dual formulations at a shared moduli point.
hypotheses.mechanism: The Schoen threefold's self-mirror property enables a causal pathway: the type IIA prepotential F (which sums Gromov-Witten instanton contributions and encodes Kähler-moduli geometry via ∂²F/∂X^a∂X^b) propagates through the mirror map to fix the functional form of type IIB periods Π_a(z). Since the superpotential W depends linearly on Π_a, and stabilization occurs at ∂W/∂z_i = 0, the IIA side causally determines which complex-structure moduli values are compatible with vacua. The mechanism is: F (Kähler side) → mirror map → Π_a (complex-structure side) → W → stabilization locus.
hypotheses.prediction: When the type IIA prepotential F is independently computed via genus-0 Gromov-Witten instanton sums and the type IIB periods Π_a are computed via the D₆-reduced GKZ differential system on the same Schoen geometry, the Yukawa couplings κ_{abc} evaluated at mirror-mapped points shall agree to within 10 percent relative error, and the Kähler metric components K_{ij̄} computed from F and from Π_a shall have correlation coefficient r greater than 0.95 across all 5 D₆-invariant moduli directions.
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If Yukawa couplings κ_{abc} computed independently from type IIA prepotential F and type IIB periods Π_a disagree by more than 20 percent relative error in two or more independent components when evaluated at mirror-conjugate points, OR if the Kähler metric correlation coefficient drops below r = 0.85, this refutes the hypothesis. Alternatively, if IIA-predicted complex-structure stabilization locus (derived via mirror map) fails to overlap with IIB-computed locus at less than 80 percent of sample points, the causal hypothesis is refuted.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: Yukawa-coupling relative agreement error less than 10 percent across all three independent κ_{abc} invariants; Kähler metric correlation r greater than 0.95; stabilization-locus overlap of at least 80 percent by point measure (at least 4 of 5 moduli directions within plus-or-minus 1 sigma).

experiment.approach: Compute the type IIA prepotential F for the Schoen threefold from genus-0 Gromov-Witten invariants using mathematical tables or modular forms; independently compute type IIB periods Π_a via the D₆-symmetric GKZ differential system; apply the mirror map t^a(z) = ∂F/∂X^a to establish coordinate correspondence; compare Yukawa couplings and Kähler metrics derived from F (IIA) against those derived from Π_a (IIB) at shared moduli points.
steps: Retrieve genus-0 Gromov-Witten invariants N_{d_1,d_2} for the Schoen threefold from mathematical literature (OEIS, Calabi-Yau databases) or compute via Batyrev-Borisov toric methods.

Construct the type IIA prepotential F(X^a) = (1/6) κ_{abc} X^a X^b X^c + (1/2) sum_d N_d (X^a d_a)^3 Li_3(q(t)) and numerically evaluate F and derivatives at Kähler moduli points in the large-volume regime.
Compute the GKZ differential system for Schoen complex-structure moduli and apply D₆-symmetry reduction from h²¹=12 to 5-dimensional effective subsystem.
Solve the D₆-reduced Picard-Fuchs system numerically to high precision (50+ significant digits) using Griffiths-Dwork method or hypergeometric-function expansion around large complex-structure point.
Compute type IIB period basis {Π_a(z)} via numerical integration of holomorphic (3,0)-form Ω(z) over D₆-invariant 3-cycles, storing results at multiple moduli points.
Apply mirror map t_a = ∂F/∂X^a to transform IIA coordinates to IIB coordinates; verify invertibility and compute inverse z_i(t_a) numerically.

Compute Yukawa couplings on IIA side: κ_{abc}^{IIA} = ∂³F/∂X^a∂X^b∂X^c (analytic), and on IIB side: κ_{abc}^{IIB} computed from period integrals; evaluate at mirror-conjugate points and compute relative error.
Compute Kähler metric components K_{ij̄}^{IIA} from F and K_{ij̄}^{IIB} from special-geometry data; compute Pearson correlation coefficient r between the 5×5 metric matrices.
Determine moduli-stabilization locus on IIA side by solving ∂W^{IIA}/∂X^a = 0 in large-volume regime.
Transform IIA stabilization points to IIB coordinates and compare against IIB stabilization locus; measure overlap as fraction of IIA-predicted points within plus-or-minus 1 sigma of IIB locus.
tools: Magma or Macaulay2 for GKZ differential-system setup
Mathematica or Python (mpmath, sympy) for high-precision numerical solving
OEIS and Berglund-Hübsch tables for Gromov-Witten invariants
Julia (DifferentialEquations.jl, Polynomials.jl) for numerical integration
SageMath or Singular for toric geometry
In-house symbolic/numeric pipeline for mirror-map computation and Yukawa extraction
experiment.estimated_effort: 8 to 12 weeks: 2 weeks to assemble Gromov-Witten data; 3 weeks to implement D₆-reduced GKZ system; 2 weeks to code mirror-map inverse; 2 weeks to compute Yukawa and Kähler metrics; 1 to 2 weeks for comparison and analysis.
experiment.data_requirements: Published Gromov-Witten invariants for Schoen threefold (h¹¹=h²¹=12); D₆-invariant moduli basis and intersection-number data from Dolgachev-Nikulev classification; GKZ lattice and charge matrix for Schoen polytope; arbitrary-precision arithmetic libraries (100+ bits); symbolic algebra systems (Macaulay2, Magma, or open-source equivalents).
experiment.expected_positive: Type IIA prepotential F and type IIB periods Π_a yield Yukawa couplings agreeing to within 10 percent relative error in all components; Kähler metric components correlate at r greater than 0.95; stabilization loci overlap at 80 percent or greater of tested points. This confirms that Schoen's self-mirror symmetry enables causal duality validation.
